string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

search.slidetext: start course start course icaos interested agency training series 401-icaos judicial issues training interstate commission for adult offender supervision
what’s icaos? training objectives icaos judicial issues training purpose authority implications rule making authority role of the state compact office compliance enforcement resources available
icaos considerations icaos judicial issues training transferred from one state to another supervised while on compact supervision returned to a sending state when an offender violates
adoption of the compact icaos judicial issues training

purposes of the compact icaos judicial issues training promote public safety protect the rights of victims effective supervision/rehabilitation control movement of offenders provide for effective tracking

authority of the compact icaos judicial issues training article i, section 10, clause 3 of the u.s. constitution – the “compact clause the crime control act of 1934 congressional consent ‘transforms’ the compact and authorized rules into a “law of the united states” texas vs. new mexico, 482 u.s. 124 (1987). cuyler vs. adams, 449 u.s. 433 (1981). compact rules supersede any state laws in conflict with them.

transfer of supervision is a privilege icaos judicial issues training there is no “right” of convicted persons to travel across state lines or to serve one’s sentence in a particular state. see, jones v. harris, 452 u.s. 412 (1981); meachum v. fano, 427 u.s. 215 (1976) convicted persons have no right to control where they live; the right is extinguished for the balance of their sentence. williams v. wisconsin, 336 f.3d 576 (7th cir. 2003), pelland v. ri,317 f. supp. 2d 26 (2004)
compliance enforcement icaos judicial issues training audits sanctions for non-compliance remedial training imposition of fines legal action in federal court
implications of the compact icaos judicial issues training

role of the state compact office icaos judicial issues training processes & reviews compact transfers and activities training resource field officers, prosecutors, judges, jails & parole boards resolves issues with other states ensures compliance with icaos rules develops & recommends in-state isc standard and operating procedures state council
collaboration icaos judicial issues training judges supervising officer prosecuting attorneys interstate compact office

relocate relocate remain in another state for more than 45 consecutive days in any 12 month period includes treatment where the stay exceeds 45 days supervision (at least 90 days remaining) supervision (at least 90 days remaining) 2 distinct criteria: oversight exercised by controlling authority which includes courts, paroling boards, etc. required to monitor regulations or conditions, other than monetary conditions monitoring supervision adult who commits a criminal offense subject to supervision released to the community under the jurisdiction of: courts paroling authorities corrections other criminal justice agency meets eligibility requirements offender offender no state shall permit an offender who is eligible for transfer to relocate to another state except as provided by these rules key definitions icaos judicial issues training

eligible offenses icaos judicial issues training deferred sentences is there a finding of guilt? given up right to trial? has a plea been entered? misdemeanants-rule 2.105 sentence = 1 year or more of supervision and instant offense includes 1 or more: person incurred direct or threatened physical or psychological harm use or possession of a firearm 2nd or subsequent conviction of driving while impaired by drugs or alcohol a sexual offense that requires the offender to register as a sex offender in the sending state is there a finding of guilt? has a plea been entered? given up right to trial? deferred sentences-rule 2.106 sentence of 1 year or more of “supervision” & instant offense includes at least 1 of the following: person incurred direct or threatened physical or psychological harm use or possession of a firearm 2nd or subsequent conviction of driving while impaired by drugs or alcohol sex offense requiring registration in the sending state misdemeanants-rule 2.105 all felons subject to “supervision” felonies felonies certain misdemeanants deferred sentences eligible offenses icaos judicial issues training

plan of supervision proposed residence proposed employment or viable means of support supervision terms & conditions substantial compliance determined by the sending state no revocation proceedings have been initiated reference advisory opinion 7-2004 request at the discretion of the sending state no offender has right to transfer 90+ days of supervision remaining substantial compliance valid plan of supervision reason for transfer justification substantial compliance substantial compliance substantial compliance plan of supervision plan of supervision plan of supervision transfer requirements icaos judicial issues training

transfer acceptance… reason for transfer icaos judicial issues training resident/resident family (88% of compact cases) other mandatory (<1% of compact cases) military member/live with military family military veteran receiving treatment employment transfers (at direction of employer) all discretionary (12% of compact cases)common reasons: treatment/school/new employment opportunities; other verified means support mandatory discretionary

reporting instructions criteria rule 3.104 no travel prior to acceptance icaos judicial issues training reporting instructions reporting instruction exceptions living in the receiving state at the time of sentencing expedited (other emergencies) both states must agree military orders employer directed transfer to maintain employment veteran services
notify receiving state if: release date changes release date withdrawn or denied submit within 120 days prior to release pre-release transfer icaos judicial issues training rule 3.105 rule 3.105
waiver of extradition icaos judicial issues training offender application for transfer offender signs prior to leaving the sending state extradition hearings not required

rule 4.101 rule 4.101 degree of supervision receiving state’s responsibility to supervise compact offenders consistent with local offenders including programs, sanction/interventions do everything you would for instate offender except extend supervision or revoke courts involved in supervision decision for instate offenders? then they should be for compact offenders!! rule 4.103 rule 4.103 term of supervision rule 4.102 rule 4.102 receiving state sending state supervision icaos judicial issues training

warrant icaos judicial issues training warrant must be issued within 15 business days written order commanding law enforcement to arrest an offender shall be entered in the ncic wanted person file national pick-up radius no bail or other release conditions rule 1.101 rule 1.101

authority to arrest and detain icaos judicial issues training an offender in violation of the terms and conditions of supervision may be taken into custody or continued in custody by the receiving state only if you have the authority to arrest in-state offenders without a warrant from the court. rule 4.109-1 rule 4.109-1

sending state retaking obligations receiving state requires retake and…….. report of ‘behavior requiring retaking’ conviction of new felony conviction of new violent crime “absconder” apprehended in the receiving state on the sending state’s warrant mandatory retake? yes yes yes yes sending state action issue warrant or order the offender to return -may ask for pc hearing issue warrant issue warrant warrant previously issued per rule 4.109-2 -may ask for pc hearing offender is not available if there are pending violent crime or felony charges unless states mutually agree see rule 5.101-1 retaking icaos judicial issues training “retaking” vs “extradition” the only way an offender can be returned to the sending state under the compact is if he originally left the sending state via transfer under the compact icaos opinion 2-2004 retaking requires warrant & detainer discretion of the sending state or required upon request of receiving state for non-compliance with a recommendation for a warrant and revocation of supervision offender charged with a new crime cannot be retaken until: charges have been dismissed sentence has been satisfied offender is released to supervision for the new offense unless sending and receiving state mutually agree to retake/return rule 5.101 & 5.101-1 rule 5.101 & 5.101-1

retaking obligations icaos judicial issues training rules 5.104, 5.105, 5.106, 5.107, 5.108 & 5.110 rules 5.104, 5.105, 5.106, 5.107, 5.108 & 5.110 sending state cost of retaking retake within 30 days establish authority of officers identify the offender ensure no detainers against offender exist ensure no extradition proceedings are pending receiving state cost of detaining no bail or other release conditions allowed for the offender conduct probable cause hearing if requested
icaos website icaos judicial issues training
resources available icaos judicial issues training

whitepapers icaos judicial issues training why your state can be sanction upon violation of the compact or the icaos rules neither judges, prosecutors nor other state officials can immunize a state from liability which results from their actions arising under the terms of an interstate compact to which the state has bound itself by legislative enactment of the compact. see alabama v. north carolina, 560 u.s._ _, 130 s.ct. 2295, 176 l.ed.2d 1070 (june 1, 2010), also texas v. new mexico, 462 u.s. 554, 564 (1983) discharge of sentences in lieu of retaking is a violation of the compact and the icaos rules empathizes that once retaking is initiated, states have an obligation to follow through with such requirement regardless of the term remaining on the offender’s supervision
icaos interested agency training series 401-icaos judicial issues training thanks for completing the course exit training + questions about icaos? visit the icaos website @ www.interstatecompact.org

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="When it is known at sentencing that an offender lives or plans to live out of state, it is important that judges, prosecuting attorneys, supervising officers and the offender are aware and consider the interstate compact requirements. The interstate compact office can provide assistance and resources when needed. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="23" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="10"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Certain offenders qualify for reporting instructions. Reporting instructions provide permission for the offender to be in the receiving state during the investigation of the transfer request. Upon receipt of a request for reporting instructions in the receiving state, replies for reporting instructions are due within 2 business days except for sex offenders. The receiving state has 5 business days to respond to reporting instruction requests for sex offenders and may be denied if the residence is not compliant with policies or laws. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="36" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" ListLevel="0" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="23" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="10"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="**The website provides direct access to a directory for each state’s compact office, online training, as well as various publications including whitepapers and a benchbook for judges and court personnel. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
